data.title: Pussycat Doll singer Carmit Bachar on living with cleft palate
data.meta_description: THE performer tells our reporter of the impact of having years of surgery after being born with a cleft palate.
data.text:
Over the past few years Carmit has continued to work in the entertainment world, singing, arranging choreography, as well as working on her own brand. “I’m still having dental issues because of the cleft palate,” she says.

“I’m now an ambassador for the Scar Free Foundation as they are hoping to achieve scar-free healing for people suffering from scars from all sorts of conditions or accidents.”

Professor Sandy says: “Over the past 20 years treatment for babies with cleft lip and palate has been improved as services have been centralised to 11 UK hospitals, to concentrate expertise and resources.

“Now families are offered psychological support as well as comprehensive medical care. The Scar Free Foundation is focusing research into not just scarring issues for cleft lip/palate sufferers but also on a wider level, to find out why bodies scar the way they do and how scientists can fi nd a way of solving the problem entirely.” For Carmit, having a facial scar is a constant reminder of her birth defect.

“No one should let scars and feeling different stop them from doing what they want in life. I truly believe that but I’m hoping science might lead us towards living in a scar-free world in my lifetime.” l Carmit Bachar is an ambassador for The Scar Free Foundation. Visit http://scarfree.org.uk/
